bestBHT.bht: The fire-filled censer signifies the impending answer to the saints' prayers, as God's vengeance is about to be unleashed upon the ungodly. By casting the hot coals onto the earth, the scene depicts the imminent judgment upon the enemies of the Church in response to the intercessory prayers of the saints and martyrs. The remarkable power of the saints' prayers is evident, as God's fiery judgments manifest through voices, thunderings, and lightnings. This imagery symbolizes the dreadful and just retribution about to be unleashed by God.

Henry Alford: The fire with which the censer was filled: the hot ashes...to signify that the answer to the prayers was about to descend in the fire of God’s vengeance.
By means of the prayers of the saints...the fire of vengeance, viz. thunders, lightnings, and the following plagues of the seven angels and trumpets, was sent down on the ungodly.
The judgments which follow are answers to the prayers of the saints, and are inflicted on the enemies of the church.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The hot coals off the altar cast on the earth, symbolize God's fiery judgments about to descend on the Church's foes in answer to the saints' incense-perfumed prayers which have just ascended before God, and those of the martyrs."
How marvellous the power of the saints' prayers!"
Albert Barnes: This is symbolized by casting the censer upon the earth, as if the prayers were not heard any longer, or as if prayer were now in vain.
The symbol, therefore, properly denoted that fearful calamities were about to come upon the earth. Even the prayers of saints did not prevail to turn them away.
This is a symbol of commotion. It is not necessary to look for a literal fulfillment of it, anymore than it is for literal 'voices,' 'lightnings,' or 'thunderings.'
Marvin Vincent: With the fire [εκ του πυρος] . Lit., 'from or out off the fire,' i e., the coals or hot ashes.
Philip Schaff: The sufferings which had been spoken of, endured at the hands of the ‘earth,’ return in judgment upon the ‘earth.’
There is no thought of mercy for the world. The prayers are for judgment only.
They express only that longing for the reign of perfect truth and holiness which is one of the most essential constituents of love, whether in God or man.
Archibald T. Robertson: The angel had apparently laid aside the censer.
John pictures the scene for us.
Came to pass naturally after the casting of fire on the earth.
John Gill: And the angel took the censer,.... The golden one before mentioned, the use of which was to take and carry in it burning coals of fire..." (43 words)

...those terrors, distresses, and commotions in the world, because of God's righteous judgments, and which particularly will be at the sound of the seventh trumpet, and the pouring out of the seventh vial..." (40 words)
...the like were at the giving of the law, Exodus 19:16; or rather of those terrors, distresses, and commotions in the world, because of God's righteous judgments..." (43 words)
John Wesley: These, especially when attended with fire, are emblems of God's dreadful judgments.
God's dreadful judgments, which are immediately to follow.

bhtAttempts.bht: The fire-filled censer in Revelation 8:5 represents the answer to the prayers of the saints, signifying that the fire of God's vengeance is about to descend upon the ungodly. This image portrays the power of the saints' prayers, as the fiery judgments of thunder, lightning, and plagues are sent down in response to their intercession. The hot coals cast onto the earth symbolize God's impending judgment on the enemies of the Church, as a result of the incense-perfumed prayers of the saints and martyrs. The scene depicts voices, thunderings, and lightnings, emphasizing the commotion and fervor of God's righteous judgments.

The fire-filled censer in this passage represents the answer to the saints' prayers, bringing forth the fire of God's vengeance upon the ungodly. The hot coals cast onto the earth signify impending judgment on the enemies of the Church in response to the prayers of the saints and martyrs. This displays the remarkable power of the saints' prayers, as God's fiery judgments manifest through thunder, lightning, and plagues. The scene is filled with voices, thunderings, and lightnings, highlighting the intensity of God's righteous judgments.

The fire-filled censer in this verse symbolizes the answer to the saints' prayers, as God's vengeance is about to descend upon the ungodly. The hot coals cast onto the earth reveal impending judgment on the enemies of the Church, as a response to the saints' incense-perfumed prayers. Awe-inspiring voices, thunderings, and lightnings accompany this scene. The power of the saints' prayers is magnified, as their intercession brings forth God's fiery judgments, representing His dreadful and just retribution.

The fire-filled censer signifies the impending answer to the saints' prayers, as God's vengeance is about to be unleashed upon the ungodly. By casting the hot coals onto the earth, the scene depicts the imminent judgment upon the enemies of the Church in response to the intercessory prayers of the saints and martyrs. The remarkable power of the saints' prayers is evident, as God's fiery judgments manifest through voices, thunderings, and lightnings. This imagery symbolizes the dreadful and just retribution about to be unleashed by God.

The fire-filled censer signifies the answer to the saints' prayers through God's vengeance, as the imminent judgment upon the ungodly is about to be unleashed. By casting the hot coals onto the earth, the scene portrays the impending punishment for the enemies of the Church, as a result of the fervent intercession of the saints and martyrs. The voice, thunderings, and lightnings accompanying this event emphasize the power and intensity of God's righteous judgments. This symbolism highlights the remarkable efficacy of the saints' prayers in bringing forth divine retribution.
